Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

ICS combines a people-driven and technology-driven care coordination model to redesign care. The primary priority for implementation has been a significant investment in a technology product which ICS has built from scratch to enable, optimize and improve the nurses in the field who are actively managing patients and working alongside care teams. Secondly, ICS continues to enhance our clinical assessments and risk assessments to enable auto-populated 90-day care plans that are based on evidence-based guidelines, symptoms management/identification and expected outcomes - there has been significant enhancements to the clinical care model and 90-day care plans in 2019. Finally, ICS works closely with hospital(s) to transform the hospital discharge planning process which is an ongoing effort and involves everything from determining optimal first PAC setting of care to ensuring patients are treated in the highest quality providers in the market.

ICS BPID 1191 experienced a significant change in practicing hospital by our PGP partners shifting almost completely from one hospital provider to another during BPCI-A implementation. This has required significant operational and implementation effort to bring the new hospital leadership and key physicians onboard with the BPCI-A program and meaningfully engage in care redesign efforts. Additionally, this has resulted in unknown target prices given this change throughout the performance period, leaving ICS with a significant "blindspot" around projected results via the monthly claims files received to date.

ICS has experienced no challenges in implementing process and procdures monitor agreements. However, to establish agreements ICS partners closely with our outside legal counsel, McDermott Will & Emery LLP (MWE) who has significant BPCI and BPCI-A experience to ensure all agreements meet all requirements of the program and other applicable federal regulations. MWE currently drafts all applicable agreements within the BPCI-A program for ICS.
NA; already in a financial arrangement(s)

ICS partners closely with our outside legal counsel, McDermott Will & Emery LLP (MWE) who has significant BPCI and BPCI-A experience to ensure all agreements meet all requirements of the program and other applicable federal regulations. MWE currently drafts all applicable agreements within the BPCI-A program for ICS.  Additionally, ICS has invested in internal data & analytics functions which continue to be enhanced to ensure proper calculations of NPRA, NPRA sharing and other program outcomes. ICS also partners with Milliman who processes all ICS claims files and NPRA files. ICS is currently working with Milliman on a process to audit and verify NPRA sharing calculations since the first BPCI-A NPRA has not occurred as of yet.
NA; we don't have relationship with a BPCI Advanced Entity

ICS believes strongly in the aligned incentives motivators under AAPMs such as BPCI-A. Therefore, we believe two-sided risk is a key value provided under these models and lends credibility to our role as a convener. Related, we believe properly incentivizing our downstream partners to improve performance and directly connecting financial reward to that improved performance yields overall better outcomes for patients. We fully align with our partners through NPRA sharing agreements which recognize the unique and direct role each individual partner plays in specific areas of care redesign which is tied to well-defined metrics under each of our direct influence.
NA; we don't participate in ICS Sharing

NA; not using any of the waivers
While we selected all waivers available under the program in our participant profile, we have not yet chosen to use or operationalize any of the available payment policy waivers.

ICS employs a variety of leaders who have in-depth experience in the BPCI and BPCI-A programs as well as decades of experience within post-acute care and care coordination. Departure of one leader will not pose an issue since all leaders possess this experience. Additionally, our clinical operations department has two clinical executive leaders to protect against any issues with a single departure.

We have not yet received our first performance period NPRA so our final results are not definitely known; however, the operational and experiential outcomes of the program have been generally as expected (caveat: the major change with PGP EIs changing hospitals during the implementation of BPCI-A which was mentioned and explained in a previous section).

ICS nurses regularly interact with patients and their families relative to the adequacy and experience of their care in all settings in which they receive care throughout the 90-day episode of care. Additionally, telephonic follow up by the ICS support team throughout the episode and once the episode ends also occurs which aim to gather information about these unintended consequences. Additionally, ICS relies on the claims data to analyze any change in patterns of care or acuity that would be unexpected in conjunction with relying on CMS' analytics process to monitor post-episode spending.

The required quarterly QPP submission for a PGP EIs to update all participating practitioners which can number easily into the 100s is a significant administrative burden, especially for convener participants who may have multiple PGP EI partners.
ICS strongly supports the BPCI-A program and has experienced an overall positive experience and results within the program thus far.
